name: Moussaka
headline: Moussaka
keywords: Eggplant Casserole,Vegetable Casserole,Casserole,Eggplant Recipes,Vegetable,European Recipes,Greek Recipes,Sauce Recipes,Lamb Recipes,Meat
recipeIngredient: 1/4 cup Greek extra-virgin olive oil, divided
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
1 large yellow onion, halved and thinly sliced
1 red bell pepper, stemmed, cored, and thinly sliced
1 (28-ounce can) plum tomatoes, pureed until smooth with their juices
1/4 cup chopped fresh flat leaf parsley, plus more for garnish
1 1/2 pounds eggplant, cut crosswise into 14-thick slices

recipeInstructions.text: For the lamb: Soak the currants in warm water for 30 minutes. Drain.

Heat 1 tablespoon of the olive oil in a 6-quart saucepan over high heat. Add the lamb, cinnamon, ginger, allspice, cayenne, and salt and pepper and cook, stirring to break up the meat, until browned, about 5 minutes. Transfer the lamb to a large strainer set over a bowl and drain; discard any liquid left in the pan. Return the pan to the heat and add the remaining 3 tablespoons olive oil and heat until it begins to shimmer. Add the onions and bell pepper and cook until soft, about 5 minutes. Add the serrano and garlic and cook for 1 minute. Add the tomato paste and cook for 1 minute.

Return the lamb to the pan, add the wine, and cook, stirring occasionally, until almost completely evaporated, about 5 minutes. Add the tomato puree and currants and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat to medium-low and simmer until thickened, about 30 minutes. Stir in the parsley and oregano and season with salt and pepper and honey, if needed. Remove from the heat.

For the eggplant: Heat the canola oil in a 12-inch skillet over medium-high heat. Season the eggplant slices on both sides with salt and pepper. Working in batches, add the eggplant slices and fry until tender and lightly golden brown on both sides, about 5 minutes. Transfer the eggplant slices to paper towels.

For the bechamel: Melt the butter in a medium saucepan over medium heat. Add the flour and cook, whisking constantly, until pale and smooth, 2 minutes. Still whisking constantly, add the milk and bay leaf and cook until thickened. Season with salt, pepper, and nutmeg and discard the bay leaf. Let the sauce cool for 5 minutes. In a small bowl, whisk together the egg yolks, goat cheese, and lemon zest and whisk into the bechamel sauce until smooth.
Preheat the oven to 400 degrees F. Butter a 3-quart baking dish or casserole dish.

To assemble: Put half the eggplant slices in the dish and cover with half the meat sauce. Top the sauce with the remaining eggplant slices, and then the remaining meat sauce. Pour the bechamel over the top of the meat sauce and spread evenly with a rubber spatula. Sprinkle Romano evenly over the top, place the dish on a baking sheet, and bake until browned and bubbly, 45 to 50 minutes. Top with more chopped parsley, if desired. Let cool for at least 20 minutes before serving.

review.reviewBody: I aways double this recipe because it's so delicious and quite a bit of work, so I serve one and put the other in the freezer for another time. Sometimes, when I'm being particularly carb-naughty, I do add a layer of potatoes. Sometimes I add a layer of zucchini to bulk it up too. I love the sweetness of the cinnamon and allspice mixed with the heat of the serrano chile and cayenne pepper. I've also made a vegetarian version with finely chopped/processed and sauted cremini mushrooms as a replacement for the lamb.

I made tis and it was absolutely lovely!!!!!! Possibly one of the tastiest things I have ever made. I did add the honey. I also used my own raw pizza sauce that I made earlier in the week. It's made with san marzano tomatoes. So yummy!!!! Also I added a layer of boiled potato slices. Fantastic!!!! Thanks Bobby!!!! I can't wait to eat it this week. It was meal prep.
Long time to make but worth it.  Will definitely make again !
Outstanding but I also added potatoes, zucchini and carrots

I typically love Bobby Flay’s recipes, so I was really reluctant to admit that I didn’t like each and every aspect of this recipe. The meat sauce WAS delicious though, as well as the eggplant. I’m Greek, and my family recipe calls for both eggplant and potatoes in Moussaka, so I added roasted potato slices for nostalgia’s sake. All great. What I didn’t love was the béchamel, as I unfortunately felt it was too floury for the amount of milk called for, which made the sauce a bit gluey and not very silky. The recipe would’ve been much better with 4 cups of milk instead of 2 1/2, in my opinion. I’ve never made a Greek béchamel with so much flour. Goat cheese was a nice touch, however.  Pretty good over all, but not perfect.

I'm not sure where I went wrong with this but although the flavors were great, it was way too tomato-y.  I couldn't really detect the eggplant either.  It was like eating a big pan of lamb bolognese sauce.  A disappointing result for such a long prep time.

Bobby knows his stuff and this one does not disappoint. It’s my default mousaka recipe and better than what I’ve had in maybe all but one fancy Greek restaurant. It’s complex but every step is worth it.
Amazing recipe!  We could not find eggplant and substituted zucchini.  We made the recipe again with a different meat and it was just as good.  We will save this recipe.

Very delicious!  My friend commented that this was better than Opa's in Los Gatos, CA. I used baby eggplants that I had on hand, and cut them in half.  The next time I make this I will use full eggplants, sliced.  I am definitely making this again, even though it takes the full two hours of prep.  It was worth the time and effort.
Delicious. Do plan 2 plus hours to make the recipe.
This was so so good. We used zucchini in place of the eggplant. This was delicious. Definitely doing this again! Thank you Bobby!

I love the wonderful additions of dried fruit and spices-I just made it using some dried cranberries and a little pumpkin spice just to relish the Autumn flavors-oh and I also used the traditional layer of thin sliced potatoes that I pre-roasted with olive oil, salt and oregano, to line the bottom of my casserole before adding the meat sauce and eggplant, and Bechamel made with Ricotta and Parmigiano and Romano...so good!
Delicious!! Best recipe for Moussaka that I have made.  Thank you!

This was good.   I subbed ground turkey for the lamb and grilled my eggplant slices after brushing them with EVOO.  My husband liked this too even tho he is not an eggplant fan like me.  I enjoyed all the steps involved   in this recipe and would make it again.

I make moussaka every year for my grandchild's birthday, always the same recipe, until this year. I used this recipe and I will never go back to the old one. Everybody loved it! This is so good!  Thank you Bobby Flay for getting me out of my rut!

This Moussaka was delicious!  It was worth every step and detail.  Now that I made it once, it will be much easier the next time - and there will be a next time!  I did substitute 2 items:  raisins for currants: ground chuck for lamb.  I didn't have currants but will stock up for the next time.  I think you could even use plant based meat and it will be amazing.  I was very pleased with the bechamel sauce and will give a heads up that you need to be patient because if you keep whisking, eventually it does get thick and gorgeous.  Thank you Bobby Flay for a wonderful recipe!

Sooo good.  I doubled the meat with pound each of lamb and beef.  Adjusted spices to taste.  Added two serranos and more cayenne as I like a kick.   Salted eggplant for an hour than baked for about 20 mins to get rid of moisture and also put in a layer of sliced russet potatoes (par boiled) in the middle.   The lemon zest takes the béchamel out of this world.   It all was very tasty and flavorful.

I have made this recipe twice now! It’s absolutely delicious! I have substituted the lamb for ground turkey (first attempt) and for ground venison (second attempt). Ultimately I believe that any kind of lean meat that you have would be great. In regard to the eggplant, I baked mine at 400 degrees. Depending on how thick you cut it, the bake time can differ. But this takes away that “uncooked” flavor that can really turn you off from eggplant. Give them a good drench in oil, salt them, and flip halfway during baking. This also gives them a great flavor! The béchamel I also substituted Swiss cheese because again, that’s what I had available. It wasn’t as fluffy as it was when I did use goat cheese, but they flavor was delicious. This isn’t a quick meal, but you’ll definitely want to make it again!

Overall, a very good recipe, but there a few things I'd change next time I make this. I would not fry the eggplant slices in oil, I would just place them in raw and let them cook in the casserole dish, because there was a bit too much grease for my taste. I used coarsely ground mutton (ground it myself) and that was a decent substitution. The recipe didn't explicitly say whether to bake covered or uncovered, and I would recommend uncovered so the moisture can escape better. The bechamel part was on point, but we used satsuma zest which was wonderful. And we used three serrano peppers instead of one, because we can take the heat here in Texas.

This dish is very tasty, however, I wish I had listened to other reviewers who said to bake the eggplant. It was so oily it was almost inedible. I salted the eggplant and let it sit on paper towels for over an hour and I let the oil heat up very well first so the eggplant would cook fast, and not soak up as much oil, but it didn't seem to make a difference. I would make it again because the flavors were good, but definitely would NOT fry the eggplant. Also omitted the currents as I didn't have any.
I've made this more than  10 times and it turns out excellent every single time. It's a resounding success and all the effort is worth it.

First of all I followed the recipe exactly as shown. I've been cooking for a long time and I generally love Bobby Flay's recipes. What a colossal waste of time (3 1/2 hrs.), money ($12+) and effort. He should have called it mush-aka. Aside from the ground lamb, this dish has absolutely NO texture. It would be a great recipe for people with no teeth and need to gum their food. I'll admit it had a nice flavor but the mushy texture killed this dish. Part of the problem is the way the eggplant is precooked in the oil. It soaked up ALL of it and then some, becoming totally limp and SOAKED with oil. I would never cook this dish again but if I did I would leave the lamb in bigger chunks (you might have to add more) and simply salt and pepper the eggplant (and maybe SLIGHTLY brown it in the broiler after a light brushing of oil). This was a LOT of work for a VERY disappointing outcome. I ended up throwing 3/4 of it away. What a waste!

This is a great recipe. I also made a few modifications and it is forgiving. I used clove and cinnamon stick instead of nutmeg. I also added a little bit a red pepper flake to the meat sauce. The wine I used was marsala and it was delicious. I also added a layer of long cut Russell potatoes to the middle to give it some hardiness. I pre boiled those for 5 minutes. The eggplant does not work in oil very well and it’s very hard to cook unless you’re a professional. My advice is like the others, I salted the eggplant for 15 minutes on both sides and then stuck it on a cooling rack and baked it at 400° for about 10 minutes. Much easier and healthier. I do not like goat cheese, so  I just used a half cup of shredded mozzarella and it worked perfect.

Luscious meld of flavors! I added TBS of lemon juice to meat sauce to add a bit of acid. Baked slices of eggplant brushed with olive oil, 400 degrees, on parchment paper, 10-15 minutes per side. Easy and not oil-soaked as in frying. Used chopped up raisons instead of currants. A delicious dish and just needs salad.
This recipe is so tasty and worth the effort, I promise! My family and friend loved it!
Wonderful! I used ground venison and it was delicious. A little labor intensive but so worth it!
The lemon brings an incredible taste to this moussaka. Delicious!! And yes, it takes a 3h total time to cook this recipe, but there are a lot of inactive time.
It's very delicious and does in fact take the whole 3 hrs 15min!

Please don't bite me, but I'm a vegetarian. And, I LOVE good food.  So I made this veggie by almost completely cooking lentils in my rice cooker.  Then I added them to the sauce & let them simmer away till tender.  In addition, I sauteed mushrooms & added them for a meaty texture. Like a few previous reviewers who were avoiding frying & canola oil, I baked the eggplant on parchment after splashing with EVOO. BTW Anonymous, I share your concern. I do use canola for baking, but I get organic.

I prefer half beef half lamb and like others like a layer of potato as well. I grill my eggplant so it doesn't become saturated in oil. To the person who wouldn't identify them self-- a touch of lemon makes a dish zing. You just come off jealous !

Sounds wonderful, except for that Canola oil which is pretty bad for you overall.

http://authoritynutrition.com/canola-oil-good-or-bad/

Freaking amazing! I replaced some of the ingredients based on the availability here in Argentina (we have everything, but some are just not affordable), so it was a beef moussaka, with Parmesan instead of Romano and random soft cheese instead of goat cheese. I also omitted the yolks because then I have lingering whites in the fridge for ever :) - still the Bechamel was pretty thick. The lemon was incredible, I'll never do bechamel without lemon again.. The mixture of flavors and texture was sublime. I get the feeling that it's gonna be even better the day after ;)
The recipe was good, but it did not taste like moussaka.  I was disappointed, especially given the time to prepare it.
beautiful!  flavors, texture,  all of it.  Great effort Mr Flay.  Thank you.

ttI just had to leave a comment! :D I've never had  moussaka forget abou cooking it! But I'm seeing a Greek guy and just to get straight into his heart I've said I'm best at preparing his national dish... So I made it...oh my! it was awesome! Also been told it was even better than his Mum's ! many thanks for this great recipe! x

This is one of the best dishes I have ever made and I cook a lot. I have friends that rave about it constantly. I follow the recipe exactly and it comes out perfectly. I have never had an issue with the sauce as some other reviewers had... Perhaps the tomatoes used were too saucy (I used San Marzano tomatoes)? Or if you don't let the wine evaporate enough in the step before you may be left with a runny sauce. It typically takes me 2-2.5 hours to prepare in my small kitchen but oh is it worth it!
Chile is the country, Chili is the pepper

Terrific interpretation of a traditional moussaka.  Really loved the lemony bechamel.  I used a pound of cooked, minced leg of lamb I had on hand.  Worked great.   Staying in the middle of nowhere, so had to get a little creative.  Replaced allspice with some nutmeg and clove.  Mixed a piece of pecorino tartufo I had with some double cream dutch cheese for the topping.  Clearly a forgiving recipe.  Terrific!

Moussaka is something every family must have a variation of the eggplant lamb custard casserole. I would not spend the time making this recipe.
The very best is Moussaka a la Grecque by Craig Clairborne from the New York Times Cookbook. I have been making this college but I lost the cookbook. Somehow Food Network printed the recipe. There is one misprint
use 1/2 cup red wine not 1 1/2. I read every moussaka recipe to see variations that I might try but the NY Times cannot be beat. Look it up on-line Food Network you will find a treasure.

An absolute comfort food! I grilled the eggplant instead of frying, since it was going to be layered with sauce. I would try crumbling the goat cheese on top next time instead of mixing into the white sauce, as I could not taste the goat cheese at all.
The best Moussaka.
Outstanding Moussaka! I prepared the meat and aubergines the night before and it came out absolutely wonderful.

Really wonderful depth of flavor.  The cinnamon and allspice are wonderful with the lamb, though I see how you could use ground beef or other meat too.  Although time consuming I found it relaxing; made meat sauce and eggplant early in day, then assembled it and made bechamel at dinner time.  It seems like you could do it the day before as we'll, then just make sauce at last minute.

Oh, my goodness. This was AWESOME. did not even have all the ingredients but I don't know how it could be any better. I LOVE moussaka and this is as good as any I have tasted anywhere. I agree the lemon zest does something really special to the bechamel sauce. I doubled the spices (cinnamon, ginger- could not find my nutmeg!) since I love that aspect of moussaka and others recommended it. Other changes (out of necessity) included: using salted butter, 1 3/4 c milk and 1/2 cup half and half, dark grapes instead of currants (added a wonderful sweetness to the lamb mixture), and only added a little dried parsely. Despite the time it takes to make this recipe I will make it again for sure!

Simple and easy. Very tasty, but prep time was a bit more than expected. My on deviation was to use zucchini instead of eggplant, and I added a pinch of red pepper flakes for just a bit of extra heat.

It was a bit time consuming, but worth the extra effort.  It took me exactly 2 hours from start to casserole assembly, but that includes washing all the dishes and cleaning up the kitchen.  Will place in oven later in the day.   I roasted the eggplant in the oven to save some time and dishes.  I just brushed them with some olive oil and lined my baking sheet with parchment paper.  I halved the the amount of plum tomato puree.  I also added some sliced potato on top of the eggplant.  The bechamel sauce with the goat cheese and egg yolk is fabulous.  It gives it that real Greek flavor that pairs nicely with the ground lamb.
My husband who does not like eggplant loved it. Baked eggplant at 350 for 30 minutes. Great flavors. Bechamel sauce with goat cheese was phenomenal! Took longer than expected but worth it.

Delicious!
Homemade sauce id perfect! it wasn't too much tomatoes and juices evaporated very quick. I also baked eggplants in the oven, next time will grill it.
I didn't use lamb, pork instead.I didn't add currants, goat cheese and peppers to the dish and was awesome!
In my opinion this dish is much better next day, sauce and béchamel set up and you can slice it like cake;

I served this as a surprise birthday dinner and it is a showstopper. I followed the recipe with superb results and included the following adjustments: forgot to add the currants (didn't miss them, increased spice to 1.5 times per the other reviews; baked the eggplant for 35 min (used olive oil spray front/back omitted the chili pepper per suggestions here. I served it with a greek salad. I keep hearing about it from people who weren't even at the dinner! The lemon zest in the bechamel sets it off and lightens the dish. A lot of work but worth it. From start to serving for me was closer to 3.5 hours.

Definitely a keeper! I baked the eggplant at 350F for 30 mins instead of frying them and it worked great!  Loved the lemon zest in the bechamel sauce!  Such a great touch! We served it with a side of arugula which provided a nice counterpoint to the richness of this dish.
Very Good.  Next time I will double the spice to give it the flavor I was seeking.  My family loved it.  Worth the effort.

One of these BEST Moussaka's I have had, and I have had quite a few! If you have the spare time to make this, its defiantly worth the investment! I have a friend who is from greece and his mother is from Lebanon and he raves over it and asks when the next time I will make this dish. He says that he prefers this even over the potato based (instead of eggplant version that he is used too! I have made this numerous times and is a great dinner party meal! Also, to cut on calories-instead of frying the eggplant I will grill it on the grill. I also double the amount of spices to make it even MORE flavorful! I love the combination of the currants in this dish as well, and the béchamel with goat cheese is to die for!!

3 generations of my family love this dish.  Follow the receipe except I brush eggplant with olive oil and bake in oven. Also leave out the hot pepper. Everyone goes for seconds. Do need to allow sufficient time for prep or break it down and make meat sauce one night finish next day.

I am very surprised that none of the reviews have mentioned the amount of tomato used in this recipe. I followed the recipe exactly and simmered the meat/tomato mix for 45 minutes, still the sauce looked way too runny. I actually spooned off some tomato juice from the sauce. The flavor was great, but again, way too much tomato in my opinion. Next time I'll use half.

I have never eaten Moussaka but it always looks so good when I see it on any of the FoodNetwork shows that I had to try it.  I used ground beef rather than lamb and raisins instead of currants and also baked the eggplant with a little olive oil, garlic salt and pepper on a cooling rack over a cookie sheet for about 15 minutes rather than deep frying.  I even invited company for dinner and we all loved it and I will definitely make it again.  I made the meat mixture a day ahead since I read in one of the reviews that it tastes better if the ingredients set a while.

Excellent! But after making moassaka several times before, I've found a few 'shortcuts'. I bake the eggplant after brushing with oil, then microwave for a few minutes to soften even more. Saves a lot of oil and time. I also add some thin sliced potatoes,softened in microwave, as I've had potatoes in moussaka. Great spice combo and flavor;-.

Made this last night for dinner...my husband had three helpings and had to make himself stop eating it!  WE LOVED IT!!! It takes awhile to make but it is worth it.  I will add this to may favorites for sure.

This is a great recipe but 30 minute prep time is way off the mark. I think it probably took me closer to 90 minutes.

Also, eggplant is a sponge. The recipe calls for heating 1 1/2 cups of oil and frying the eggplant in batches. My first batch soaked up all of the oil, so I had to keep adding more. Next time I will grill it rather than fry. Other than that, this recipe was great. Haven't made moussaka in decades, but I will definitely make it again soon.
I make this with venison/antelope. It easily makes 2 pans.  The kids love it & I am frequently presented with an eggplant and the request to make it again.

Wonderful, easy recipe.  I omitted the currants, as we don't like them. But other than that, pretty much went exactly by the recipe.   I used all lamb, and it was fine for our tastes.  Thanks to my CSA box, I had a lot of eggplant to use up, and this was a great way to do it.  A little time consuming, but this can certainly be made ahead if you like.  Be sure and put the casserole dish on a baking sheet if it's filled to the brim like mine was!
great, lemon zest great touch

This recipe is fantastic.  Instead of one large casserole I made 3 loaf pans;  cooked one for dinner; froze the remaining two.  Only a few little changes to the original recipe:  I did half lamb and half ground chuck (per earlier reviews/suggestions,  I grilled the eggplant on the outdoor gas grill instead of frying, I used 1 T dried oregano vs. 2 T fresh.  This recipe has now become one of my top 'go-to' prepare ahead recipes.  I love it, love it, love it!!!!

I prepared this on yesterday. I will say it takes longer than what is stated but worth it. However, I will use both ground beef and lamb the next time.  The lamb over powered it for me as so stated by Bobby's competition.   I will add this to my favorite recipes list and make again.

I just made this last night for a dinner party. WOW!  My guests noted that they tasted different flavors in every single bite, and lamb haters went back for secoonds! It's very labor intensive but if you have the time, it's well worth the effort and is a nice change from boring standards! I would make this again!
First review I've written in my life.  This was so fantastic!  Maybe the best meal I've ever had.  Melts completely in your mouth.  Deserves 7 stars in my opinion.
my mother grew up in Greece and made Moussaka since i can recall and i'm now 67...this was the best i've had. we used 1/2 ground beef and 1/2 ground lamb and a Hatch,NM chile in place of the serrano.
Best ever, now I understand why Bobby won.  Perfect amount of heat, excellent meal all the way around....
Very delicious! Great combination of eggplant and lamb with all other spices
Delicious!!! One of my favorites. Very different from the same old meals.
